Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They recognize the importance of being present at weekly services regularly
Story: The shrill site alarm jolts me from my work, echoing across the half-built structure. My foreman’s voice cuts through the noise, “Drop everything! Muster point, now!” I grab my hard hat and join the stream of workers heading for the exit, my heart pounding. It’s Sunday morning, and I’d promised myself I’d make it to church today—no excuses. My pastor always says, “Worship is not just a habit, it’s a commitment.” I know my church family expects me there, and I feel the weight of that promise. But here, on the site, safety is everything. The rules are clear: when the alarm sounds, you don’t hesitate, you don’t question, you just go. My coworkers count on me to follow protocol, to be part of the team. As I walk toward the muster point, my mind is torn—between the call of my faith and the demands of my job, between the need to belong at church and the responsibility to my crew. The tension knots in my chest, and I wonder which part of me I’ll have to let down today.
